context: Leftists playing word games. Any medically trained by  person knows a full term gestation is 40 weeks divided into four trimesters. Pre-term refers to a gestational age between 22 - 38 weeks. Full term generally considered 38-40 weeks and post term greater than 40 weeks.  Late term is not medically defined; but, commonly refers to gestational ages past 20 weeks or viability outside the womb. Perinatal generally speaks to the period between birth and six weeks of age; but, can extend to up to one year postpartum.

replies.context: So defining it as 15 weeks isn't a mislesding word game?

replies.context: I start with the baseline that no one has a right to someone else's body.

On some things, yes, though I doubt we agree on whether abortion should be legal based on his post trying to bring up murder in an abortion debate.
How could you disagree with terminating a human life being murder? Of course that isn't the current legal definition, but you can't believe it is moral in any sense.

That (terminating a human life) isn't murder when done legally, so your question would need more context.

Whether we consider abortion moral/immoral is irrelevant to calling it murder. Murder is a matter of legality, not morality.  That said, I'd agree abortion (outside of medical necessity) is immoral.  Of course, outlawing abortion would also be immoral, which is why I'm pro-choice on abortion. No one has a right to so eone else's body. 

Do you consider it moral or immoral to have a right to someone else's body?

"Murder is a matter of legality, not morality."

As always, murder has more definitions than solely the legal one.  

"That said, I'd agree abortion (outside of medical necessity) is immoral."

Why?

"Of course, outlawing abortion would also be immoral"

How so?  

"No one has a right to so eone else's body."

If you compel someone else to be dependent on your body, through no choice or fault of theirs, why should your bodily autonomy be sacrosanct?

Murder is by definition a crime/illegal.  It's a matter a legality, not morality. Considering something immoral doesn't mean it's illegal. It doesn't even mean it should be illegal.

The same reason anyone considers anything moral/immoral, personal experiences, upbringing, interactions with others.

The quote after the "How so?" question, answers the question. No one has a right to someone else's body. 

It also answers your last question. Granted, you may not understand that if you think people should have a right to someone else's body. Personally, I'd rather we didn't revert to slavery.

"Murder is by definition a crime/illegal."

A quick look in the dictionary proves you are wrong.  "Murder" is not exclusively a legal concept, so, why are you pretending otherwise?  It has a specific legal definition, but it also has a general definition.  

"The same reason anyone considers anything moral/immoral, personal experiences, upbringing, interactions with others."

In other words, you believe abortion is immoral because of your feelings?  There are objective standards other than the law, even if you choose to ignore them.  That certainly explains why your morality has no backbone - it's always a relative "standard" for you.  

"Granted, you may not understand that if you think people should have a right to someone else's body. Personally, I'd rather we didn't revert to slavery."

If you compel someone else to depend on your body, through no choice or fault of theirs, they have every right to depend on your body.  You've deprived them of their choices, so you should be required to provide for their needs, at the very least until their care can be safely transferred to another willing and able guardian (the same obligation legally recognized for parents and their children).  You, apparently, feel that holding people to the consequences of their own choices is "slavery," which, again, indicates that you still have no clue what the words you use actually mean, or, that you will dishonestly twist the meanings of words to fit your absurd ideology.

A check of the dictionary proves I'm right, actually. 

While those are other words, they have no relation to what I mentioned. Do you always try to make up positions to assign others?

We have no objective moral standards, just all of our subjective ones we all make.

No one has a right to someone else's body.  Contrary to your claim, there is no legal obligation to the contrary regarding parents and their children.  I'm all for holding people to the consequences of their own actions, actually, but there you go making up positions again.  If you're incapable of having g an honest conversation, there's no point to having it at all.  I'll consider those strike two. If you go for strike three, we're done. It's a waste of time to continue with you if you refuse to be honest.
